description.text:
This is a filament spool holder based on MrMdR's design. Main changes:
  • it requires less filament than the original
  • it has an inset for the bearing so that it doesn't accidentally gets stuck and also leaves about 2mm more room for the spool's edge
  • it has been recreated in Solidworks. The SDLPART is provided, feel free to change the parameters around!
    • You will need two of these to hold a single pool of filament. The holder has been designed for M4 bolts and 624 bearings (4mm inner diameter, 5mm thickness).

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height

Infill:

20%

Assembly Print two of these filament spool holders.
For each of them, you will need:
  • 2x M4 bolts (at least 16mm long)
  • 2x M4 nuts
  • 2x 624 bearings
    • Assemble as seen on the photo.

The "4-Chambers Birdhouse" is an entry for the Makerbot: Thingiverse Birdhouse Challenge.  
The outside design is clean and simple, while inside, the birdhouse is very functional. The name "4-chambers" is used to describe the birdhouse's four living chambers used to nurture a newly hatched bird. Each chamber provides food and safe shelter, as well as access in, around, and out the whole birdhouse thus creating a safe growing environment for the hatchlings.

Components:
1) 4-Chamber Main Structure
2) Roof with Food Storage Cylinder
3) Top Cap
4) Four 0.0730in metal screws Instructions/ Assembly:
a. Attach then screw together the roof into center of main structure.
b. Fill the top of roof with bird food then insert top cap over.
c. Either hang birdhouse with string or place atop sturdy structure.
d. Listen to birds wake you up every morning with sweet chirping.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1349W8iwCEB Based on this design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:73690 Improvements were the base (the old design tipped backward easily), and I added a place to type your name, plus two logos: an Apple logo and a Power icon.
A common 1/4" bolt fits through the hole. Bolt length depends on the width you customize the holder to be.

I brought it into TinkerCAD because I wanted to make the holder work with my phone (iPhone 5S) with a case on it. You can easily re-size the stand in TinkerCAD for your phone (create a block that is the dimensions of the base of your phone, then tweak the holder until that block fits). The base and holder are glued together, so the width of the hinge will remain the same. 
To edit the text in TinkerCAD, double click on it and you will see you can change the words. When you download the model, you'll want to delete the icon/logo you're not using.

This is an update to thing: 23936 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23936). Essentially the same design but with a smaller outer diameter (2.75" vs 3") and some small vanes to help with motor cooling. I noticed that my batteries were getting pretty hot after doing 3D maneuvers. I noticed that the spinner is almost the same diameter as the inner opening of the cowling. This design update is intended to try and remedy this. Haven't printed it out yet, but will soon.
Print out the base and the spinner. Tap the base holes with M3 threads. Use M3 x 6-7mm socket head cap screws to hold it together.

So this one is weird. I'm just posting it in case someone else has a similar issue. You can get a little more explanation from this video: https://youtu.be/IQm6s9r01Is Long story short, we have to check my dogs urine to monitor her PH levels. So we got some condiment cups and I built a little extender so we can get under her without having to be to intrusive. But these could double as a condiment holder/extender if you wanted something like that. Also since all the parts are extendable, you could easily design something to attach to them extender pieces. I printed all parts out of PLA at 0.3mm layer height and no supports. Then I attached them with #8 1/2 inch nuts and bolts.

title: RepRap Prusa X End Motor Braces

description.text:
My Reprap Prusa is still in it's early life stages.  Amongst some of the problems I have had to solve one is the X end motor parts which are a little flimsy.  
One problem that this created for me is that tightening the X carriage belt is difficult. The reason is that there is a fair amount of flex in the plastic part.  I have read others who feel that the part has been stripped down a little too much and now is flimsy.  Obviously you could create a new part with some more plastic in there to make it sturdier.
However this means getting your printer up and running just so that you can strip it down to add the improved part.  I was looking for another way to strengthen the part.  In my parts cupboard I had some aluminium angle bracket which I shaped and bonded into place.  
I have created an SCAD file  with the parts in it, though obviously this is to give a model to work from not to print from.
With this alteration the X motor end becomes rock solid and tensioning the X carriage belt becomes a lot easier.  I can't comment on if it improves the print quality noticeably as I won't have before and after to compare but I would imagine it would help if you are having backlash problems on the X axis.

Buy some 1.5mm angle bracket from your local hardware store.  Aluminium is fine and easy to manipulate, you could use steel though if you are happy to put some extra work in.
Cut, drill and file your aluminium to shape.  The parts on the pulley side of the stepper motor will probably be enough, but additional strength can be gained by adding the brace at the non-pulley side as well.
The brace at the bottom of the pulley side is bonded in place as seen on the pictures.  I used araldite two part epoxy which forms a very strong bond.  
The brace at the top of the pulley side is not bonded in but clamps stepper motor very firmly to the plastic.  By spreading the force you can tighten better without breaking the plastic.  You could bond it in, but replacing a dead motor would become near impossible.
The brace on the non pulley end of the motor is bonded to the plastic.  It is made up of two parts and cuddles the stepper motor.
Tie wrap the parts as the epoxy dries and then attach and tighten your belt.  You should see very little if any movement of the stepper motor.

author: Justblair

title: Extruder Pointer / Indicator for Thing-O-Matic MK6

description.text:
This is a pointer or indicator for the Thing-O-Matic MK6 Stepstruder to show when the extruder motor is actually turning. I find it very helpful to know if/when the extruder motor is skipping steps and the easiest way is to watch the shaft rotation (or feel the filament feeding with your hand). But the MK6 shaft end is flush with the support bearing, so there was no easy way to mount any kind of flag/indicator. Up until now, I just used a piece of blue tape. I figuired that I could use a magnet to mount a pointer. The motor shaft is about 6mm diameter, so at first, I tired a single 1/4" magnet to stick to the end....but there are some magnetic fields going through the motor shaft, so the magnet did not like staying centered on the shaft. So next I tried 3 smaller magnets in a circle, and that worked perfectly. I ended up using some 1/8" diameter by 3/8" long rare earth magnets I had left over from some other project that I bought at K&J Magnetics:
http://www.kjmagnetics.com/proddetail.asp?prod=D26. I pressed them into the printed part and it works perfectly. This is designed for the MK6, but it may work on other models just as well. I am not sure since I do not have others. I made 2 designs......one is a one piece design, the other is a two piece design that get's glued together with some acetone. They are functionally equivolent, just l look a bit different. I think it is a necessary upgrade to any printer.

author: C6SUMMER

title: Filament guide for Prusa i3 Hephestos

description.text:
English below Guía de filamento para la Prusa i3 Hephestos de BQ. Me he hecho un marco de PVC para tener los filamentos a mano y necesitaba una guía que permitiera que el filamento entre desde cualquier angulo, así que diseñé esta guía con una ventana ancha. update
Al quedar a ras del marco, la cadeneta de cables la empuja hacia arriba en impresiones que tengan cierta altura, así que he diseñado una nueva versión más alta que da unos 5 cm de margen y evita que se enganche.
Además he aprovechado el espacio extra para incluir ranuras para tarjetas SD. He subido 2 versiones, de 2 y 4 ranuras. La de 2 ranuras va perfecta, la de 4 no la he probado y no sé que tal se sujetarán ya que tienen solo 1 cm de profundidad, si alguien la prueba que comente el resultado en los comentarios.
Ah, también he cortado el anillo de guía para poder pasar el filamento aunque ya esté cargado en el extrusor, que a mi siempre se me olvida! English Version
This is a wide filament guide for the Prusa i3 Hephestos. I've made a PVC frame to arrange the filaments and I wanted a filament guide that allows the filament to come from a variety of angles.
update
I've created an improved model to avoid the cable chain to crush into the guide. It's a taller design so the chain won't hit the guide even with tall prints. I've used the extra space to allow SD storage slots. I've already printed and tested the 2 SD slots model and works well. The one with 4 slots may not work as good because the slots are just 1 cm deep and may not hold the SD card correctly.
I've also included a cut in the guide ring to be able to introduce the filament even after loading it into the extruder.

Prusa i3 Hephestos

My First desk lamp shaped a cat. Very easy to print and assemble. Can sit, lying ect... IMPORTAN NOTICE be very carefull when do wiring!!! Always shield the wires and please use LED bulb. Items need for assemble:
1 screw M4 50mm (back)
1 screw M4 60mm (front)
2 bolt M4 or wing nut
1 GU10 lamp socket. (http://www.ebay.co.uk/bhp/gu10-lamp-holder)
1 wire connector
1 GU10 LED lamp
1 wire with switch and plug
3 screw nail (10mm) (two for the GU10 socket one for the neck)
Super Glue The back and the shoulder have to be glued together.
GU10 socket hav e to be secured with two screw nail and the wires goes throu the little holes. Put the connector on the back of the socket plate. Glue the head back to the head.
You can put the screw nail into the neck from inside the head, maybe you can drill a hole to help it. Little tricky but if you put a washer uner it it can be easily tightened.
If you hold vertically the head and put the bulb in it you can find the holes for the GU10 socket.
The shoulder shoud make the legs spread a bit for stability.

I have not printed thse models out myself, but I am planningon doing so in the near future. I will update the models and description after printing. I have cut the models to simplify printing, but you must note that some models will need raft and/or supports. This model does not need supports at first glance but I will leave it at your discretion. Use rafts if your plastic as a tendency to curl from the build platform. All of these models have been repaired with Netfabb, but please, if you have printed this model and found there are mistakes or you have an idea of how to make this model better, please post a comment and I will try my best.

tren de juguete imprimible.
Requiere pegamento, para unir las piezas, a ser posible de dos componentes.
el archivo rueda delantera stl, hay que imprimir 6 ruedas. El archivo rueda stl hay que imprimir 2 ruedas, a ser posible en filaflex, para que no patinen, o pegarles posteriormente una goma, elástica alrededor, para evitar que patine.
Necesitas:
pegamento de dos componentes o similar
juego de limas planas y redondas de 3mm o menos.
1 portapilas de 4 pilas
1 tornillo M3X30mm para sujetar el motor
6 tornillos M3X10mm para las ruedas, la rosca va en el chasis y las ruedas son pasantes, hay que repasar los taladros con una lima redonda
1 trocito de alambre o clip, para unir la locomotora al vagón. todos los taladros, hay que repasarlos con una lima, con cuidado hasta ajustar bien los tornillos.
el motor utilizado es el modelo Gear Motor-DG01D, con reductora, disponible en muchas tiendas de electrónica y robótica. Muy fácil de montar y divertido.

title: Ultimate 50mm Rotating Spool Holder - MakerBot Replicator 2

description.text:
Quickly change 50mm filament spools using this amazing free spinning spool holder. The holder rotates freely to reduce friction and ensure smooth prints. Convenient slots enable you to quickly secure the spool using a filament clip. As a bonus, you don't lose filament clips. Both 1.75mm and 3.0mm filament clips are part of this project. Video of the spool holder in operation: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ee25BwZchII
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j-4nSkeWlNw This spool holder requires a bolt and lock nut commonly available at most hardware stores. The cost is usually less than 40 cents.

Requirements: 5/16" x 3.5" hex head bolt, 5/16" lock nut, 1/2" socket, and printed parts
  • Print parts without support or raft
  • Snap off supports from the Spool Holder Mount
  • Insert bolt in the back of the Spool Holder Mount until flush
  • Slide the Spool Holder onto Spool Holder Mount bolt
  • If the Spool Holder doesn't rotate freely run the bolt in and out to wear down imperfections. You can also try 300-600 grit sandpaper on the smooth section of the bolt.
  • Attach the lock nut to the bolt with a 1/2" socket.
  • Tighten the lock nut so that the Spool Holder still spins freely.
  • Attach new Spool Holder to back of MakerBot Replicator 2 and enjoy!
    • Spool Mount
    Infill 100%
    Shells 2
    Height 0.1mm Spool Holder
    Infill 25%
    Shells 2
    Height 0.2mm Filament Clip
    Infill 15%
    Shells 2
    Height 0.1mm

comments.text: Very nicely done. I will be printing this out for my FlashForge Creator Pro! I hope I wont need to mod it to fit! I LOVE IT!
comments.author: agilliam

comments.text: I adapted this to my Replicator 1 Dual also... But had to make a couple changes to the mount, the spool center worked fine.  On the mount i had to remove the lip around the back side of the mount, with that lip on there it wouldn't fully seat into the hole in the back of the replicator.  I see some comments from those that made them for their Rep 2 that it sits at an angle, this is because of that lip on the back.  I imported it into TinkerCad and removed that lip making the backside of the mount flat, now it fits perfectly.  Also the 3 1/2" bolt was a little short and wouldn't fully engage the nylon portion of the nylock nut.  To remedy this i removed 1/4" or 6.35mm from the end of the snout that the bolt goes through on the front side of the mount.  I also put a flat washer between the spool and the mount and pressed a washer into the front end of the spool.  This gives it a lot better durability over its life because the nut won't be rubbing into the plastic of the spool and the mount and spool won't be rubbing together also.  I took a 5/16" drill bit and ran it through both the mount and the spool a few times to clean and smooth the insides for the bolt and then added a very thin coat of some silicone lubricant.  Now i can adjust the nut to adjust the tension of the spool so that its just the right amount of free spin.

This may work on printers other than a Robo3D/R1/R1 Plus
The 8mm rod(s) are 24 mm shorter than your glass length. ** Warning remember your working with glass! be sensible in the amount of correction you try to make. If you apply TOO much shim you could break the glass. I some cases the glass is between $30-$50.00 When I created my 330mm Y Rails upgrade for the Robo 3D
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1154745
I learned that my bed glass was .02 mm lower at a certain point that at other points. When your auto leveling a larger printable space it's expected that you will find larger variations that when using a smaller area. I personally have my auto level routine in the firmware reaching out to points at 5 mm and 305 mm when it auto levels the Y area (this is a firmware config change). Ok now for the fix.
If you did the 330mm Y rail upgrade, you will have the old standard length rails. I created the (printed in red in the pictures) rod holders to use these standard length left over rods for this design. Print 2 of the blocks and place one of the left over 8mm rods in the holes and slide the slots onto the glass. This gives you a support bar which you can lift your glass in a location that has a low spot. I used some washers I had laying around to accomplish this shim action. If you don't get the right lift to get you a perfectly level bead area, print 2 more blocks and use the 2nd 8mm bar you have. I personally printed mine is PLA because the heated area does not extend into the area where the block sits. IF you upgraded to a 300 mm length bed heater, you had better use ABS or nylon which has a higher glass temperature.

title: HTC Desire Belt Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Simply put it is a holder for the HTC Desire and it goes on your belt! Comes in two parts, one is the holder for the phone. It is contoured for the phone but I have no 3D scanner so it was done by trial and error by eye. It is a close enough match for this job. There are two clips either side that hold the phone in place. These are somewhat tight and it takes a bit to get the phone in or out of it. However once in it will not fall out (almost certainly anyway!!). The second part is actually the belt clip from this thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11666 I just copied the part I needed for this. The clip is embossed with HTC for a bit of branding. I printed this in two colours, Buttercream and Princely Purple. [UPDATE]
Version 2 is now available. Changes are a reduced height of the top section so that it doesn't press on the ear while making a call (for the odd time a smartphone is used to actually make a call!). The side clips are reduced and chamferd on the top edge to make it easier to remove the phone and do not require support to print. From my Simple HTC Desk Stand I took the profile and added it to the top half of the holder to increase support for the phone. There are holes in the lower section in order to reduce the amount of material used. And the height and width have been slightly reduced (0.5mm & 1mm respectively) for a snug fit.

Print out the two parts Use V2 of the holder, other version is left for historical purposes, the holder may need support on for the clips not for V2. The opening is a tight fit for the belt clip so it would need a little filing to fit snugly. Although a good fit, it may be best to glue the clip to the holder with some super glue. Pop the phone in. I put one side in then, with my palm, push the phone in. To remove, you will need to pull the clips back and push onto the camera lens cover. May need a little force but one side will start to come out, then turn over and remove the phone totally. Not needed anymore. Just push the phone in and then you can pull it out easily either by pulling behind the power button or pushing out with the lens gently. Have been thinking, would it be better to print in ABS? Would that allow for more flex then PLA allows?

The idea was coming from the movement of birds, their wings length is changing when they fly back to their nest. The house space is different from bottom to the top. The narrow on the top allow sunlight goes as deep as the bottom.   
There are some 1 inch holes with threaded, i want to show an idea about "Customizable" and "replaceable", which is also the core idea of 3D printer technology. with the Threaded connector people can print different color or materials bird-stand(birds can stand outside), transparency hole caps(make it like a small window for bird), and anything you want.

Motivation: I constantly find myself in need of a small amount of light at will, and the cell phone doesn't always cut it. My goal is to build a small but powerful flashlight ring. Details:
I've tried two switch mechanisms so far. The first one had the head slide laterally, perpendicular to the finger, but it wasn't quite comfortable. This present model slides instead forward and backward. This also is not ideal.. it requires both hands to turn on and off, and the top is prone to falling off. I think the next version will try to have a twisting activation instead. Software:
Model was designed in openscadpy (first project, sorry for the poor state of the code): github.com/hmeyer/openscadpy Hardware:
Model was printed on an up! printer ( pp3dp.com ) My intent is for this product to be Open Hardware, under the TAPR OHL: tapr.org/TAPR_Open_Hardware_License_v1.0.txt

Tools:
Up! 3D printer, or equivalent
support removal hand tools
wire cutters
soldering equipment Bill of Materials:
(1) ring base, printed
(1) ring head, printed
(2) coin cell battery, http://www.sparkfun.com/products/337
(1) 1 SPDT slide switch, http://www.sparkfun.com/products/9609
(1) triangular proto board, http://www.sparkfun.com/products/8887
(3) bright LEDs
(3+) extra lengths of wire Assembly Instructions:
  • Print both parts. The size of the ring can be changed in the openscadpy file, but you might have to print a few different sizes to see what fits. Be careful though.. I've definitely had a few too many stuck rings through the process..
  • Wire up the triangular proto board. This is a bit tricky.. and certainly the way I did it is not the best way. The slide switch is in the center on one side of the protoboard, and the LEDs are on the opposite side. Once through the board, group and solder the positive and negative leads with one another. attach the positive group to one side of the slide switch. The other side of the slide switch will be running to the positive battery lead, and the negative group of the LEDs will go to the negative battery lead. Once together, test the circuit. then, push the protoboard unit into the ring head.
  • Install coin batteries. The best way I've found to do this is to slide wires into the gap so that an inserted coin cell will connect and hold it in place. Run two of such wire on the LED side of the gaps; one going to the slide switch, one going to the LEDs. Add one more such wire connecting the two batteries. insert the batteries: positive end of one running into the slide switch, negative end of the other running into the LEDs. Be careful of short circuits.. unfortunately, I haven't yet found an easier way to do this. NOTE: I unfortunately lost one of the coin cells.. so in the pictures, there is only one battery installed. Also, it's a lot less bright than it could be.
  • Orient the completed unit so that the slide switch can snap into the ring base.

title: Bre Pettis Birdhouse with Easter Egg!

description.text:
Birds occupy the space where the Replicator was invented. And as a bonus, a birdhouse easter egg!.... Bre Pettis staring at the poor birds wherever they are in the birdhouse (hint: take a look at the inside). Freaks out birds and people. I've included the full house, but it will take a boatload of raft and support. So I split it in half, and I'm not sure this would solve the support problem, but easier to clean out! Either way, funny, disturbing, and gentle on the environment. Special thanks to Bre Pettis for open sourcing his head.
Mashed up on Tinkercad.com No birds harmed in testing.

title: SmartrapCore new slideX (V. 3.2) for 6 & 8mm rods, with 2 optionnal fanducts

description.text: This is the new version of my slideX for the SmartrapCore (designed for my wooden box printer, but it will probably work just as well with the alu version), after http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001419 I made before… I made several little or big improvements, mostly about cooling the hot end and the printing zone. The main body part is available for both 6mm and 8mm rods, just pick the one for your setup. You can also choose between two different printing zone cooling systems : one for a traditionnal fan, and an other one for a radial (turbine) fan. I suggest you try this last one, it might just blow your mind off… ;) Update (V. 3.1b Dec. 22 2015) : because of some cooling issues, I had to redesign the hot end fan and Zsensor support, and the bottom part of the radial fanduct. It's also a bit easier to print, now. :) Update (V. 3.2. 01/25/2016) : new fanduct bottom part (032b). It's smaller, more simple, and seems more effective, so it will be the replacement for the 031 version. Update (02/08/2016) : added a 032d version of the radial fanduct bottom. It's an extension of the 032b one, with deflectors on the sides that help to keep the air flow focused on the printing zone while keeping the printed shapes of the air exit away from the hottest part of the hot end. I'm using this one now and it seems quite effective.

comments.author: laxde

comments.text:
1) So far, all my designs can be printed with no material support. :)
2) I actually only print with PLA, never tried anything else.
3) I printed it and I'm currently using it, but didn't find time yet to make pictures. I'll do that ASAP.
4) The printing zone cooling fan is controlled with Cura, yes, and I'm still trying to find the best settings. The main thing is that, with the radial fan, it's extremely efficient… So much that it's actually TOO efficient, when using with my heat bed. So I guess it's important not to put the fan to 100%, and set Cura parameters so that it'll start only after some height so that the first layers will stick properly before cooling anything.

author: Creader

description.text:
3D triangle generator creates right triangles. It lets you specify the top angle, the height, the depth, the proportion of the top depth to bottom depth, allows centering, and inverting.  
It uses some good 'ole high school level math (Pythagorean Theorem & Sohcahtoa) piped into a dynamic polyhedron module I created for super fast rendering as well. No union() or difference() methods at all! :D   
I created this to be able to easily create support structures in my openSCAD models for tall thin walls. By using a low upper angle and tall height it will help "brace" the wall with limited extra material if placed properly... I've uploaded the "almost" (needs testing) finished STL of the object I created the support triangles module for to give an example of how I used it :)

title: Pololu Mini Maestro Enclosure for EEZYbotARM

description.text:
Here's an enclosure I whipped up to house the Pololu Maestro Servo Control Board called out in the EEZYbotARM instructable. 
I made the walls thin as to not interfere with the mechanics. I also included a couple of spacers if the screws on hand don't fit the depth of the enclosure. With the spacers, up to a 7mm screw can be used. I wound up repurposing the servo control horn screws that were left over. 
The enclosure pictured is friction welded at the 3 points of contact with the base support (2 corner bottom, and top center).
Enjoy!

description.text:
ALL OF MY DESIGNS ARE MOVED TO YOUMAGINE
A grille over a fan looks nice and helps keeps junk from falling inside your device (and keeps fingers out too). I never seem to have grilles sitting around and seldom bother ordering them so I wind up with naked fans. Now I can just print one up.
Can be used to cover ventilation holes in cabinets as well.
Features a recessed vane area so the blades don't hit the grille. You can set the number of vanes, number of circles and all sizes including vane and circle thickness and center circle thickness.

The included STL is for a standard 60mm fan with 4 vanes.
For others, open the SCAD file and set up the parameters for your fan. They're pretty self explanatory.
The side towards the print bed is the outside (away from the fan).
Instructions: print, use.

Note: Due to inherint flaws in this design, I developed an alternative modular cooling system for the Prusa i3 that can be found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:230654. I suggest checking it out before you make one of these. This is a dual 40mm fan filament/J-Head nozzle cooler for the MakerFarm Prusa i3 with an MK IV J-Head hot end and a Greg's Accessible Extruder, although it should work with most Wade's/Greg's extruders using the MK IV J-Head. It provides 330 Degree cooling of the filament. One fan is dedicated to cooling the J-Head, the other is dedicated to cooling the filament.

I have added a mirrored version of the DualFanFlowDirectors360.stl file, to allow the use of 40mm X 40mm X 20mm fans for filament cooling in place of the 40mm X 40mm X 10mm fans, since they were previously obstructed by the extruder stepper motor.

Each of the 4 pieces were printed separately. The DualFanFlowDirectors360 part was printed with a 0.35mm nozzle at 0.3mm layer height. Smaller layer heights seem to help this part to print more successfully given some of the steep overhangs. After each part was printed successfully, the DualFanShroud, DualFanFlowDirectors360, and the FilamentCoolingDuctDifuser were super glued together. The DualFanMount should snap onto the J-Head, and has holes for the screws that go into the extruder (Greg's Hinged Accessible Extruder in this case). If printed correctly, the DualFanShroud should snap into the DualFanMount, and the FilamentCoolingDuctDifuser should encircle the nozzle of the J-Head.
NOTE: This cooling duct will not work with the J-Head MK-V! It is designed for the MK-IV, which is 10mm longer than the MK-V.

comments.text: It's just taller, so it still fits in the same 40mm X 40mm hole, but it sticks out of the fan shroud by 10mm instead of sitting flush with the top. The side that cools the filament was obstructed by the stepper motor for the extruder before, so I mirrored it to switch which side cooled the filament and which side cooled the J-Head. The 40mm X 40mm X 10mm fan seems to work fine for cooling the J-Head, so it shouldn't matter that it's beneath the extruder stepper motor.

title: Idler Pulley - All plastic, no bearings

description.text:
This is an idler pulley assembly for the X and Y-Axis. It is inferior to a steel ball bearing assembly but works fine so far. It is always good to have one as emergency replacement. These pulleys may squeak like hell. :D Note: Friction will be much stronger and the rotation may be eccentric leading to lower print quality. Use only for emergency until your replacement bearings arrive.
  • Version 1: Outdated version with a rod diameter of 5mm. Can break during operation but still works in broken state. Y-axis only.
  • Version 2: New version with higher rod diameter of 6mm. Slimmer but robust bracket. Made for X and Y axis. Thumbscrew is included.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3 mm Nozzle, 0.2 mm Layers

Notes: Additional brim is included for rod for better adhesion. The rod may overheat during printing (not operation) and loose its precise diameter. This must be compensated by sanding afterwards, or by printing two widely separated rods at the same time.
You maybe have to sand the rod after printing. You can use silicone spray for lubrication. Oil (WD40) somehow increases friction.

In mathematics, a conic section is a curve obtained as the intersection of a cone with a plane. Traditionally, the three types of conic section are the ellipse and circle (the circle is a special case of the ellipse), the parabola, and the hyperbola. The circle is of sufficient interest in its own right that it is sometimes called the fourth type of conic section.
The project is to design a model of a circle as a conic section. Additionally the instructor can specify the parameters of the section and ask the students to show the necessary calculations. As a further design challenge both parts of the cone can be designed interlocking so that they can be assembled to a complete cone.

This was designed in FreeCAD using only basic primitives.
Illustration from wiki commons.

Objectives: This is an introduction to CAD teaching position and boolean operations on primitives. The project can also be used to help visualize mathematics. Audiences: The project could be used in parallel with teaching the mathematics of conics. Preparation: A basic understanding of primitives, position, and boolean operations. Also a basic understanding of the mathematics involved. It is a simple design that should be easy to make in any design program of the instructors choice Steps: Make a suitable cone and cube, place the cube or cone as needed and subtract the cube from the cone. Results: Learning basic placement and boolean operations. Also a better understanding of the mathematical concept of conical sections. One can also use this project to introduce the loft operation by using two circles and the loft utility.

I had a few rough landings with my T-28, and ended up cracking the firewall.  I repaired it with epoxy several times, but it kept breaking in the same spot.  So I cut out the bad bits and designed up this insert for the firewall.  Problem solved!  I have only tested it twice with landings, but it survived both of them (running over a ~12mm diameter stick on one).

This shield allows you to connect a HP C6602 inkjet cartridge to your Arduino turning it into a 96dpi print platform. It only uses 5 pins which can be jumper selected to avoid other shields. It is designed with a Arduino Mega footprint but fully supports both the Arduino and the Arduino Mega. It uses all through-hole components to make assembly easy even for beginners. Features
Compatible with Arduino and Arduino Mega
Uses only 5 user selectable pins
Stackable (up to 11 Inkshields on Ardunio, 15 on Mega)
On-board 20V boost converter for inkjet head
Accepts 9-12V input via optional power connector or from the Arduino Vin
Auxiliary input header offers support for other microcontrollers
Auxiliary output header supports an extension cable to the inkjet head
Power and Pulse activity LEDs
ISCP header and Reset button
All through-hole components This will be the first official release location. For the most current information visit:
http://nicholasclewis.com/inkshield/
https://github.com/NicholasCLewis/InkShield A production run of this project was successfully funded via a Kickstarter here: http://kck.st/oAGeza Description of files:
InkShieldLibrary.zip - Regular Arduino Libraries/Examples (You should download the NEW version)
InkShieldLibraryNEW.zip - Regular Arduino Libraries/Examples (updated version - found a few bugs when finishing the Mega version)
InkShieldMegaLibrary.zip - Arduino Mega Libraries/Examples
InkShieldLiteLibrary.zip - Minimal Arduino Libraries/Examples
InkShieldPCB.zip - Kicad Schematic and PCB Layout

• Allow program to mimize to tray. Allowing program to run in background for print stream purposes.
  • Will automatically import prints from gcode files. (Repetier Host slic3r & Simplify 3D).
  • Imported prints from gcode will show in new print stream dialog.
  • Print stream dialog shows the user prints that have occured while the program is running.
  • Added tool tips to various components.
  • Save file and reports will now be stored in the local folder. "C:\Users\\AppData\Local\3DPrinterFilamentTracker\FilamentInfo.txt".
  • Various code improvements.

• Add % used to each print.
  • Add a cost field to the filament and for each print.
  • Stats feature showing total number of prints, filament used, cost, etc.

• Auto save the info file every 5 minutes if a save is needed.
  • New format and look for the export to HTML.
  • Add print using the right click menu.
  • Edit print/filament icon change.
  • changelog dialog added.

• Users can now create filament type, weight, and length. These will be saved to the save file and will be used to populate the combo boxes on the add filament dialog screen.
  • The save file will auto update to the correct format when using v1.1.
  • Auto check for updates.
    • This is a small program I have been working on for the past couple weeks designed to keep track of your printer filament. It's as easy as adding filament then adding prints to those filaments. Just download the .jar file and double click it to run it. Java is required to run the program. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3JT2ombsjBg Code is here https://github.com/MrOwnership/3D-Printer-Filament-Tracker

description.text: I liked the concept of using a CD as the bottom, inspired by Gyrobot, both for drainage and easy cleaning, plus shortening the time to print. So I modified the Cool Birdhouse to take a CD/DVD for a bottom. See Cool Birdhouse for additional info about the design and instructions. (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:116693). Kudos to Gyrobot and the Birdhouse Bauble for inspiring the use of CDs! (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:105561)

Added a CD as the base - you must print this at actual scale (1:1) for this to work.  Otherwise, print the original Cool Birdhouse or use the CD model provided by Gyrobot.  Note that there is a bridging challenge at the base, so your printer must be well-tuned. There are a number of bridging and torture test models on Thingiverse to aid you in tuning your settings.  
NOTE (7/23/13): I am working on a V3 that eliminates the bridging and should be more printable.

Replace your boring household light switch covers with something a little more interesting. Connect your favorite Lego pieces or Mini Figs to create a wall mounted Lego landscape around your switch! You can use existing screws. this thing was designed, realized and printed in the phenomenal Engineering dept. of New River Community College, under the guidance and encouragement of Jeff Levy. For more info about the NRC Engineering Design Technology program, click here:
http://www.nr.edu/cadd/

Printer Brand:

Stratasys

Printer:

uPrint SE

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Medium to High

Notes: The tolerances on this are not great. I'm no engineer... just a beginner. Legos will stick to it, but may be loose in some places. Your best bet is to attach a flat lego piece (2X4 works well) first, then connect additional pieces to that. Good luck! *** Gang... It was indeed saved/uploaded in inches. If it makes your set up any easier, the final specs are: 3.0 X 4.79 INCHES. I think on some occasions I had to re-size it the slicing software before printing. Sorry about the confusion.
